day_trip_planning.overview: Bozeman is a perfect base for full-day guided fly fishing adventures. Trips can include float or walk/wade, and guides will match your skill level and seasonal river conditions.
planning_steps: Decide whether you prefer float or walk/wade trips.
Choose a guide service based on rivers you want to fish (Gallatin, Madison, Yellowstone, or spring creeks).
Book your trip at least 1–2 weeks in advance during peak season (June–Sept).
Check with your guide about included gear vs what you’ll need to bring.
Pack layers, rain jacket, sunscreen, sunglasses, hat, snacks, and water.
Consider combining the day with a brewery stop or riverside picnic.
tips: Early morning or evening trips often yield better fishing results in summer.
Waders and boots are usually provided if needed — confirm ahead.
Tipping your guide ($75–$150) is customary for a full-day trip.
Plan lodging close to the guide pick-up point for early morning starts.

must_have_items: Fly rod (4–6 weight for most area rivers)
Waders and wading boots (non-felt soles preferred)
Polarized sunglasses (for spotting fish + eye safety)
Rain jacket (Bozeman weather can change fast)
Fly box with local dry, nymph, and streamer patterns
optional_items: Fishing license (can be purchased online or at fly shops)
Camera or phone with dry pouch
kid_friendly_additions: Snacks and fun outdoor activities for breaks

spring.local_tip: Fish slow seams and deeper pools in spring runoff windows. Nymphs work best early, then switch to dries on warm afternoons.

summer.local_tip: Terrestrials dominate July through early September. Fish edges of grassy banks midday for big dry-fly eats.

fall.local_tip: Watch for low-light BWO hatches and switch to small nymphs or streamers during low pressure days.

winter.local_tip: Focus on mid-day warmth windows and fish the East Gallatin or spring-influenced spots. Nymph deep and slow.

spring.description: Cooler water temps but productive days — especially for midges and blue-winged olives.

summer.description: Prime dry fly season. Expect strong caddis, PMD, and hopper hatches in July and August.

fall.description: Brown trout aggression peaks. Streamer season kicks in along with late BWO hatches.

winter.description: Tough conditions, but midges and slow-moving nymphs still work. Focus on sunny days.

spring.description: Early season brings cold water but active fish. Great time for streamers and early dries.
spring.local_tip: Try mid-day when the sun warms the water slightly. Gallatin access near Four Corners is often reliable.

summer.description: Peak dry fly season! Lots of hatches and high water activity.
summer.local_tip: Use hoppers in the heat of the afternoon. Consider twilight trips for rising trout near the East Gallatin.

fall.description: Cooler weather and low, clear water bring on technical fishing and big streamer action.
fall.local_tip: Fish get picky — go with small dries in the morning and strip streamers in the afternoon.

winter.description: Slow season but possible on mild days. Focus on midges and nymphing deep.
winter.local_tip: Stay low and slow — use a tight line nymph rig. Most productive water is below warm outflows or spring influences.
